div.h1: CORONAVIRUS: WHAT YOU NEED TO KNOW NOW

div.script: $(document).ready(function() {CheckScript('ModuleView');CheckScript('Mustache'); });
$(document).ready(function() {CheckScript('ModuleView');CheckScript('Mustache'); });

img.style: display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;
img.title: News Alert

p.span: Governor Mike Dunleavy announced the statewide school closure of all K-12 public and private schools is being extended from May 1, 2020, to the end of the 2019-2020 school year. Despite the need to extend school building closures, student learning will continue, per the Ketchikan Gateway Borough School District Distance Learning Plan.

span.span: View the KGBSD Credit Earning and Grading During 2020 COVID-19 Closure

p.span: - Makeup Work Guidance in the FAQ's

p.a: Check out our Students & Families page for updated Online Meetings times and our At Home Activities guide.

div.script: $(document).ready(function() {CheckScript('ModuleView');CheckScript('Mustache'); });

p.span: The health and safety of our students and staff are paramount, and we are closely monitoring the spread of COVID-19.
Based on the rapidly evolving situation of the Coronavirus Disease-19.

span.img: Contact US! Have Questions? Need Help?

span.strong: The School District in partnership with the community Emergenty Operations Center (EOC) Team is asking all students and parents of our school community to follow the shelter in place.

em.strong: Starting on Monday, March 23rd until April 6thall certified (teachers and specialist) and classified (paraprofessionals) staff will work from home, except for a few designated KGBSD personnel.

span.em: All KGBSD buildings will be closed for staff and community usage.

p.span: As a reminder, the CDC always recommends everyday preventive actions to help prevent the spread of respiratory viruses, including:

li.span: Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. If soap and water are not available, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer.
Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth with unwashed hands.
Avoid close contact with people who are sick.
Stay home when you are sick.
Cover your cough or sneeze with a tissue, then throw the tissue in the trash.
Clean and disinfect frequently touched objects and surfaces.

h1.aria-label: HELP! My student doesn't have a computer to use for home learning?
h1.span: HELP! My student doesn't have a computer to use for home learning?

h2.span: The Ketchikan School Districts student computer distribution is in full swing. If your student still needs a device to connect with their teacher you can arrange for us to deliver by calling 225-0744.

h1.aria-label: (HS & MS ONLY) But my Quarter 3 wasnt what I wanted. I was counting on Quarter 4 to bring it up!
h1.span: (HS & MS ONLY) But my Quarter 3 wasnt what I wanted. I was counting on Quarter 4 to bring it up!

p.span: But my quarter 3 wasnt
what I wanted
. I was counting on quarter 4 to bring it up!

There is still time left in the year for this to be addressed. Work with your teacher. You may be able to re-do or submit work from quarter 3, in an effort to bring up your grade. Your teacher may also give you some alternative assignments as a way to demonstrate your understanding of prior-taught content. Your communication with your teachers is essential. Talk with them about your options. We want you to succeed!
What are the rules on doing work to raise my Quarter 3 grade? (HS/MS)

li.span: All assignments or activities from Quarter 3 are eligible to be resubmitted or improved (up to the full original maximum points). If it is not practical or appropriate to re-do the original assignment, the teacher may choose to offer an alternative assignment, based on the same content and for the same number of points,
Maximum of one submission, re-do or alternate activity per assignment.
The last day to submit work is Friday, May 22, 2020

Participation based grades may be earned/made-up (up to the full original maximum points). However, the teacher will determine the appropriate substitute activity or assignment to replace the participation that would have occurred during Quarter 3

h1.aria-label: I am a Senior, what does this mean for me?
h1.span: I am a Senior, what does this mean for me?

p.span: If you were in good standing and passing all your required courses for graduation at the end of Quarter 3 (April 3), you will graduate on time.

Even if you were not passing all of your required courses, We want you to know that there is still time for you to graduate this May. You will need to work with your teachers to ensure your quarter 3 grade is passing, so you earn credit for the class.

p.b: What about Class Rank, Valedictorian, Salutatorian, Honor Cords, and all that?

p.span: These will still be determined in accordance with Board Policy 6146.10 and Exhibit 6146.10. Note that the 4th quarter mid-point check will still be referencing the quarter 3 grade that will determine overall semester grade for the course.

In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, on April 16 Ms. Lougee will be asking the school board to suspend part of the graduation requirements related to Alaska State Jobs Application, Work/Volunteer hours, and the WorkKeys/ACT/SAT assessment.

p.b: Will there be a graduation ceremony? What about prom?

p.span: Based on guidance from Health Mandate 11, social gatherings are prohibited. This would include events such as prom and graduation. However, we know it is important to try to maintain tradition and to celebrate the accomplishments of our Seniors. We will be looking at and discussing options for alternative celebrations. We will also be holding Senior family meetings soon to discuss how we will recognize our graduating class. Ultimately, our decision to proceed will be based on protecting the health and safety of our students, families, and community. We will also comply fully with any governmental guidance or requirements regarding gatherings.

h1.aria-label: What will Grading, Due Dates, & Late work look like at the High School?
h1.span: What will Grading, Due Dates, & Late work look like at the High School?

h1.aria-label: Will my High School student get credit for 2020 Semester 2?
h1.span: Will my High School student get credit for 2020 Semester 2?

p.span: The KGBSD School district will provide distant, at-home learning options for students based on essential learning topics. Any assignment or assessment submitted to a teacher will be returned with feedback with the goal of improving student learning and understanding.

Spring 2020 Semester grades will be the same as a students 2020 Quarter 3 grades. There will not be any new 4th quarter grades. Semester credit will be awarded for any credit-bearing class with a passing quarter 3 grade (0.5 credits per semester class).
Revilla High school will develop a personalized plan and communicate it directly to those families.
But my quarter 3 wasnt
what I wanted
. I was counting on quarter 4 to bring it up!

There is still time left in the year for this to be addressed. Work with your teacher. You may be able to re-do or submit work from quarter 3, in an effort to bring up your grade. Your teacher may also give you some alternative assignments as a way to demonstrate your understanding of prior-taught content. Your communication with your teachers is essential. Talk with them about your options. We want you to succeed!
What are the rules on doing work to raise my Quarter 3 grade? (HS/MS)

li.span: All assignments or activities from Quarter 3 are eligible to be resubmitted or improved (up to the full original maximum points). If it is not practical or appropriate to re-do the original assignment, the teacher may choose to offer an alternative assignment, based on the same content and for the same number of points,
Maximum of one submission, re-do or alternate activity per assignment.
The last day to submit work is Friday, May 22, 2020

Participation based grades may be earned/made-up (up to the full original maximum points). However, the teacher will determine the appropriate substitute activity or assignment to replace the participation that would have occurred during Quarter 3

p.b: What about my online classes with Alaska Digital Academy or my Dual-Credit classes with UAS?

p.span: If you were enrolled in one of these classes prior to the closure, you will be expected to fully complete these courses in accordance with the guidelines of those programs. Your grade for the classes will be based on your completion of the required coursework and will be reflected on your transcript.

p.b: Will there be final exams or end of course/end of semester exams?

p.span: No. With the exception of online/dual-credit courses.

p.b: My quarter 3 grade is fine. Do I even need to show up for my classes?

p.span: Yes, please do! While there will not be any penalty for missing class (we know it may be a challenge for some families), it is still really important that you continue to meet with your teachers and classmates. We will continue developing and growing our instructional model. We want you to keep learning and to stay connected to school. If you miss classes because of communication challenges or scheduling conflicts, your teachers will be reaching out weekly to check on you and make sure things are ok and to see how we can help.

p.b: I want to do more. Can I take some extra classes with Alaska Digital Academy?

p.span: We want to support our students who wish to go above and beyond. If you wish to take additional courses through Alaska Digital Academy, please contact your school counselor. You will be expected to complete those courses in accordance with their policies and requirements. For more information about AKDA, go to: alaskadigitalacademy.org
p.b: To earn credit, any course that is started during the Spring 2020 semester must be finished before the end of the semester (June 3)
What about FastTrack? Can I just enroll my student in FastTrack now?

p.span: For the remainder of the school year we are asking parents and students to remain enrolled in their current school to complete the school year. IF you want this option for your child for the 2020-2021 school year, visit
and fill out our New Student Enrollment Form. You may contact FastTrack at 907-247-2127.

p.b: Will there be a summer school for students who need to do credit recovery? K-8 Summer School? What about the Jump Start program for incoming Freshmen?

p.span: We do not yet know what our capacity will be for these summer programs. Much will depend on the progression of the disease within our state and community. For students who wish to participate in these programs, we will be working to develop systems to address this need. More information will come later.

h1.aria-label: Want to help KGBSD feed kids in Ketchikan during the COVID-19 school facility closures?
h1.span: Want to help KGBSD feed kids in Ketchikan during the COVID-19 school facility closures?

img.alt: Free and Reduced Lunch Application Icon
img.title: Free and Reduced Lunch Application Icon

h1.span: Want to help KGBSD feed kids in Ketchikan during the COVID-19 school facility closures?

div.strong: Complete the Free and Reduced Price Meal Application online TODAY!
Why would this help? The meals are already free?

div.div: KGBSD receives reimbursements for meals provided to students who qualify and helps us make meals free to everyone during the school closure. If more households qualified, it would help us keep the program going for as long as possible. Plus, we know many families have experienced a loss of hours or income. Applying now could qualify your household for free or reduced-price meals even after school starts back up. Help us offer meals to more of Ketchikan's kids, including your own!

div.strong: But I already completed an application earlier this year and was denied. Should I really apply again?

div.div: If you were denied earlier this year, apply again! You can apply as many times during the year as you need and can use your past month's, current month's,ornext month's income. Reduced hours or a change of income as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic could mean you now qualify for free and reduced meals for the rest of the year.
Apply anyway! Especially if you have had a change in your household size and are caring for more individuals.
Don't have online access? Request a Free and Reduced Price Meals Application from any of the school lunch sites during meal pick-up, or request one for delivery!
Need assistance? Call Dawna Hull at 907-228-8803 or emaildawna.hull@k21schools.org.
THIS INSTITUTION IS AN EQUAL OPPORTUNITY EMPLOYER

h1.aria-label: How does my student use Zoom with their teachers?
h1.span: How does my student use Zoom with their teachers?

p.span: Your teachers will be using a conferencing tool called Zoom to connect with students. This is an easy to use tool that will link your student with teachers!

Before joining a Zoom meeting on a computer or mobile device, you can download the Zoom app fromour Download Center. Otherwise, you will be prompted to download and install Zoom when you click a join link.
You can alsojoin a test meetingto familiarize yourself with Zoom.
Teachers will be sharing their Zoom links with your students.

span.strong: If you have any issues please use the "Chat" icon on the side of this webpage.

h1.aria-label: Free Breakfast & Lunch During School Closure
h1.span: Free Breakfast & Lunch During School Closure

a.img: Click to view the KGBSD Menu

p.span: KGBSD Food Service Plan during School Closure

div.p: Beginning March 23rdand lasting for the extent of the school closure, KGBSD will be offering food service for children 18 years of age or younger at the following locations:
Grab-n-go meals will be provided at each facility Monday-Friday in drive-through style pick up at each location during the following times:

Owing to the need to social distance and keep KGBSD facilities clean and secure, meals will be offered in a drive-through fashion, meaning parents, guardians, or caregivers can pull up to the curb at a designated entrance at each of the locations, and staff will come out to greet you at your vehicle, take names and meal orders, and deliver meals directly to your vehicle. Look for signs or staff at each of the locations for pick up spots!
These meals will be provided under the model of the Summer Food Service Program, with the following requirements:

ul.li: All children ages 0-18 will be served at any location listed above. (Schoenbar will be the main hub for food distribution.)
Children must be present in order to pick up a meal, in accordance with federal requirements.
Meals will be provided based on the current March Lunch Menu, posted on the districts website.
Children and their parents will be allowed to pick up both meals (breakfast & lunch or lunch & snack) at each of the open pick up times, 2 meals per student/child per day.
Students and children receiving meals must provide names upon pick up.

If students and children with food allergies or meal modifications plan to receive a meal, their parent and/or guardian/caregiver will need to RSVP to Food Service Manager no later than the morning of meal service to be prepared by the lunchtime distribution period: Call 907-228-7215 or emailbrock@k21schools.org

Parents of students who are homebound, medically fragile, or who cannot otherwise access transportation to one of the approved locations should contact Katie Parrott, Business Manager at 907-247-2116 or emailparrott@k21schools.orgto discuss options

div.p: Any questions or concerns? Contact Katie Parrott (907) 247-2116katie.parrott@k21schools.org
This institution is an equal opportunity provider.
We know that this is an uncertain and difficult time for students, parents, and families. KGBSD is committed to supporting our community in tangible ways as much as we can during this time.
Katie Jo Parrott
Business Manager

h1.span: Free Internet

span.a: The Ketchikan School District is gathering information regarding home internet connectivity and available devices for our students. TAKE THE SURVEY.

hr.p: GCI is working directly with the Department of Education and Early Development and theAlaska Council of School Administrators to help get Internet connectivity to K-12 students and educators who may not currently have access.GCI is offering the entry-level plan with Wi-Fi equipment to students and teachers forfreeuntil May 31, 2020 and are waiving credit checks and deposits for service and equipment.

p.strong: For Households that Currently haveGCIInternet Service Statewide

hr.p: Alaskan households that currently haveGCIInternet plans can receive a free upgrade to the next level plan for no additional cost through May 31, 2020. Customers can callGCIor visitMyGCIto upgrade. The purpose of this upgrade is to support customers who may be working from home, have household members in school, and provide greater connection for those who are social distancing in the coming days and weeks.
KPUannounced on March 13, that in response to Covid-19, increased all residential fiber internet customers to a minimum of 30M/30M, to allow for work from home and online school for free.
AnyKPUcustomer that wants to increase their speed to the next higher plan will get that for free for two months.
That is not new.KPUhas always done that for customers. It just requires a call to our offices at 228-5474.
Customers on VDSL would be subject so some limitation as to how high they can be taken.
On March 13KPUeliminated all internet overages for customers and businesses for the next two months (at least)
For people wanting new service, we MIGHT be able to turn up service ifKPUservice existed in the home previously.
New customers receive the first two months' internet for free, which is standard forKPU.
However, if someone did not have service previously withKPUand the wiring does not exist, then we cannot install it.
For the safety of the customer and the techs, we will not allow techs into people s homes to do wiring for the near future.
As a last note,KPUis not disconnecting any phone, internet or TV customer who cannot make their payment, and we are waiving late charges for at least 60 days.
Anyone who cannot reach our office at 228-5474, can call me directly at my work extension which is forwarded to my cell: 228-5458.
Thank you and stay safe - KPU

h1.aria-label: March 23- April 6th COVID-19 School Closure Plan
h1.span: March 23- April 6th COVID-19 School Closure Plan

span.b: KGBSD March 23- April 6th COVID-19 School Closure Plan

div.p: KGBSD is developing a Delivery of Lessons Plan for while school is closed. It is our hope to begin rolling out the plan by March 26, 2020. This plan will be designed for each level of learning and your childs building principals will be sending out notifications prior to the roll out. Our goal is for students to read, write, communicate, and engage in continued at-home learning experiences during this period.

The first weeks of school closure (Monday, March 23 to Friday, April 3) will not include any teacher-directed instruction; however, teachers will be available to support students, to collect and grade previously assigned work, and will be reaching out to contact students and families.We want to make sure that none of the activities/lessons provided these coming weeks have penalties attached to them.While teachers will be providing guidance and feedback on assignments given,students should not be penalized for non-participation or failure to complete tasks.This has been the approach other districts in Alaska have taken as well.

Students can participate in optional, self-directed activities posted on the districts website. Self-directed activities will be neither required nor graded. These activities will be across the content areas so each child can choose activities that suit their interests. Additional information for families who need access to technology and connectivity will be provided soon.

p.strong: Here are some tips to help you support your child during this time:

ul.li: Balance screen time and non-screen time activities.
Know how Covid-19 is transmitted and take action to stay healthy.
Establish times for quiet and reflection.
Remain mindful of your childs stress

div.p: This plan will continue to build should the school closure last past April 3, 2020. We ask for patience and continued support as we continue to communicate the plans to you.

h1.aria-label: Will students have to go to summer school to make up for days missed?
h1.span: Will students have to go to summer school to make up for days missed?

span.style: color: #222222; font-family: Verdana, Geneva, sans-serif; font-size: 15px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; background-color: #ffffff; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial; display: inline !important; float: none;

strong.span: Gov. Mike Dunleavy announced that schools will remain closed to students through the end of the school year. No traditional classes will be held, though teachers are providing distance learning.

p.strong: A universal preapproval relating to school closures is being provided and the Governor is suspending the regulatory requirement that school districts apply to DEED to receive a school calendar waiver. The suspension of these requirements are contingent upon distance providing distance-delivered educational services through the duration of school closures.

h1.span: Athletics

div.p: Durning this mandated closure, our district will join others in the region to suspend all athletic activities, including practices.

p.span: The Alaska School Activities Association is announcing the cancellation of all 2020 spring events, championships, regular season contest, and practices.

div.p:
This decision is based on the following:
On Friday, March 20, 2020, the Alaska Department of Health and Social Services, the Alaska Chief Medical Officer and the Office of the Governor issued Health Mandate 8.1 which states Public and private schools are closed to students through May 1, 2020.
Students will receive instruction through distance delivery methods. All after school activities will be suspended during this time.
For safety reasons, ASAA bylaws require students to have completed 10 practices prior to participating in contest.
The guidance of State Health Officials and the Alaska Department of Education and Early Development.
For any additional information please visit ASAA's website atwww.asaa.org.

h1.aria-label: How do I sign up for KGBSD Text Alerts?
h1.span: How do I sign up for KGBSD Text Alerts?

div.span: Ketchikan Gateway Borough School District uses the SchoolMessenger notification system to provide timely communication to parents and staff members on matters such as attendance, lunch balances, transportation, school activities, and emergencies. This system is designed to send phone calls, emails, and text messages; allowing you to select how you prefer to be contacted.

div.div: The district will only use the service to provide information that is timely and relevant.
To participate in the text messaging service, you must indicate your willingness to receive text messages to your phone. The process is simple and only takes a few seconds to complete.

div.strong: Simply text any one of the following words to the number 68453: subscribe, option, yes

div.div: Youll know you were successful if you receive the following reply message:You are registered 4 SchoolMessenger notifications. Reply STOP to quit, HELP for help.

In addition to performing the opt-in process above, youll want to ensure that the district has your current wireless number(s) in our student information database. If you havent already provided that information to your school, do so.

h1.aria-label: Will there be PEAKS testing in 2020? - NO
h1.span: Will there be PEAKS testing in 2020? - NO

p.span: In SHORT, NO! State testing has been canceled.
The state of Alaska has applied for and received a waiver from PEAKS 2020. All accountability measures will use 2019 testing results.
FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE March 23, 2020
DEED to Receive Waiver for Assessment and Accountability Requirements from U.S. Department of Education

JUNEAU In an effort to support school districts in response to Novel Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19), the Alaska Department of Education and Early Development (DEED) submitted a request to the U.S. Department of Education (US ED) to waive certain requirements of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act (ESEA, section 1111) related to assessment and accountability requirements. US ED has reviewed the request and intends to issue a formal approval of the waiver request in the coming weeks. DEED will begin work to implement the waiver while US ED processes the formal approval.

In the near-term for Alaskan schools, this means the immediate cancellation of statewide assessments: PEAKS content area assessments in Mathematics, English Language Arts, and the Alaska Science Assessment; the alternate assessment, Dynamic Learning Maps (DLM); and the English language proficiency assessment, WIDA ACCESS for ELLs (including Alternate ACCESS). In addition to waiving requirements for assessments, certain requirements for school accountability and reporting will also be waived by US ED.

DEEDs assessments and accountability teams, and the entire staff at DEED, will continue to work to support Alaskas school districts towards the best outcomes for students, now and into the future, as we work through the challenges ahead.
For the latest updates on COVID-19 relating to schools, please follow DEED on social media at @AlaskaDEED and visit our website at
education.alaska.gov/safeschools/infectiousdisease

The Alaska Department of Education and Early Development provides information, resources, and leadership to support over 130,000 students in 503 public schools across Alaska. The mission of the department is to ensure an
Excellent Education for Every Student Every Day
Media Contact:
Rochelle Lindley
, Information Officer, (907) 465-6535

h1.span: Guide to Using Zoom

div.p: Zoom is an online meeting software that the KGBSD School District has chosen to use for communication for the Coronavirus in-home learning.

img.title: Important
img.strong: ALL Staff has had a Zoom account created and has been emailed an invitation. If you can not find your invitation email help@kgbsd.org for assistance.

p.strong: District Zoom Training will be provided.

p.span: KGBSD Expectations
1. Welcome Message: Once a day (as your health allows) have a scheduled time of 10 min to meet with students online face to face. ( A district schedule will be published.) Starting March 30th, 2020.
2. Office Hours: Use Zoom and/or Google hangout to check in with students and provide support.

img.title: Computer image
img.style: display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;
img.a: Click HERE for the KGBSD Zoom Training Presentation

p.img: Watch How to find your Zoom Personal Meeting ID

p.span: Resources

span.a: Comprehensive Guide to Educating Through Zoom
Tips & Tricks: Teacher Educating on Zoom
Tips & Tricks for Administrators and Staff using Zoom

h1.span: Google Hangouts

div.p: Google Hangouts provides a tool to communicate with families. Please use your district account for communicating with families and do not use your personal accounts or phones.
You can use Hangouts to:

ul.li: Start a chat conversation or video call.
Make phone calls using Wi-Fi or data.

div.p: Hangouts sync automatically across devices. If you start a Hangout on your computer, you can continue your chat on another device, like your phone.
